title: Get Psyched!: Keep a good mental state, don't procrastinate | Culture | thepenn.org
text:
Procrastination, which is just delaying or postponing tasks, is a universal human experience. Do you ever sit down to study, only to find yourself scrolling through Instagram reels, reorganizing your room or tackling any other possible task that isn’t a priority? If so, you’re not alone.
While it may feel like a simple bad habit, our cognitive functions, which include memory, attention, planning, reasoning and decision-making, play a central role in procrastination.
- Poor time management
Psychologists call this the planning fallacy, where people underestimate the amount of time it takes to complete tasks (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). This underestimation reduces urgency, leaving us vulnerable to distraction. - Reward systems
The brain is wired to seek pleasure and avoid pain. When we encounter a stimulus such as social media, dopamine is released from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and sent to the nucleus accumbens, reinforcing the behavior with feelings of satisfaction (Schultz, 2015). If past academic efforts didn’t yield the expected reward, for example, a disappointing grade, the brain learns to associate studying with discouragement, lowering motivation to repeat the task. - Decision fatigue
When faced with overwhelming or complex tasks, our prefrontal cortex becomes overloaded, leading to avoidance. Instead of tackling the assignment, the brain seeks relief through easier, low-effort activities like cleaning or scrolling.
Outside of cognitive functioning, our emotions influence whether we move toward or away from a task.
- Aversion to negative emotions
Anxiety, stress and boredom often accompany schoolwork. Avoiding the task allows temporary emotional relief, but research shows that avoidance maintains and even strengthens procrastination over time (Sirois & Pychyl, 2013). - Perfectionism
Although it may seem like perfectionists may work harder, studies show they often procrastinate more (Flett, Hewitt, & Martin, 1995). Fear of failure and not meeting unrealistic standards can paralyze progress. - Lack of confidence
Low self-efficacy (belief in one’s ability to succeed) strongly predicts procrastination (Bandura, 1997). If students doubt their abilities, they may avoid tasks altogether to protect their self-esteem.
While emotional and cognitive factors play a significant role in procrastination, motivation determines whether we view a task as worthwhile.
- Low motivation
When tasks feel uninteresting or irrelevant, procrastination comes easily. This is especially true in academic settings where students feel disconnected from course material. Additionally, mental health struggles such as depression can reduce intrinsic motivation, further fueling procrastination. - Lack of clear goals
Humans are purpose-driven. Without clear, meaningful goals, tasks seem pointless, making them harder to accomplish. Locke and Latham’s (2002) research on goal setting highlights that specific and challenging goals increase performance more than vague or easy ones. - Extrinsic vs. intrinsic rewards
When we rely solely on extrinsic motivators (grades, money, or punishment), tasks feel like chores. Intrinsic motivation, which is motivation driven by curiosity or personal growth, produces deeper engagement and less procrastination (Deci & Ryan, 1985).
Understanding the psychology behind procrastination is the first step. The second step is learning strategies to counter it. Research suggests several effective approaches:
- Implementation intentions (“if-then” planning)
Gollwitzer (1999) found that forming concrete action plans, such as “If it’s 7 p.m., then I will sit at my desk and open my textbook,” helps people initiate tasks automatically, reducing avoidance. - Task chunking
Large assignments feel overwhelming, so breaking them into smaller, manageable parts reduces decision fatigue. Completing small steps also activates reward circuits, providing a motivational boost. - Cognitive reframing
Instead of thinking “I have to write this whole paper,” reframing the task as “I’ll write one paragraph” reduces pressure. Over time, this builds momentum and lowers emotional aversion. - Self-compassion
Research by Sirois (2014) shows that self-compassion lowers procrastination by reducing the shame spiral. Treating setbacks with kindness encourages persistence rather than avoidance. - Balancing extrinsic and intrinsic motivation
Finding personal meaning in tasks, such as connecting assignments to long-term goals or values, enhances intrinsic motivation. When tasks feel purposeful, they’re easier to begin and complete.
Procrastination is not a sign of laziness, it is a psychological pattern influenced by how our brains process rewards, how our emotions respond to stress and how motivated we feel by our goals. While it can feel frustrating, research suggests that simple cognitive and behavioral strategies can break the cycle.
By reframing tasks, setting concrete goals, practicing self-compassion and finding personal meaning in our work, we can shift from avoidance to action. Ultimately, overcoming procrastination is less about time management and more about managing our minds.
